data.text: Management of gastro-oesophageal reflux in Infants / MSEGL-21028 / 1.0

Many infants who present with recurrent regurgitation/ vomiting and/or irritability to Primary Care, receive a diagnosis of gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) and are referred to secondary care centers for further assessment.

The majority of such infants have already been prescribed anti-reflux medications (often multiple medications and over prolonged periods of time) and have been trialed with a number of different formulas.

Whether or not these interventions have been effective is often not clearly documented and there is a risk that essentially healthy infants are being exposed to ineffective drug treatments over prolonged periods and exposed to unnecessary investigations. The parents of these children are often very anxious and concerned that severe GORD is causing their infant to cry with pain and that there is a risk of long term oesophageal damage.

The purpose of this guideline is to provide a consistent approach to the clinical management and diagnostic work-up of infants with suspected GORD. With particular emphasis on the need to document the presence of reflux, to establish a causal relationship between reflux and symptoms and to evaluate the efficacy of therapies in a serial manner.

table_items.text: Gastro-oesophageal Reflux- the normal physiological process of passage of gastric contents in to the oesophagus.
Gastro-oesophageal Reflux Disease- reflux that has pathological consequences like oesophagitis, weight loss, recurrent respiratory symptoms.
An effortless reflux of the gastric content up to oropharynx or above. Also known as obvious GOR.

Reflux is very common and affects at least 40% of infants.
Reflux usually begins before the infant is 8 weeks old.
Regurgitation is most common around 4 months of age decreasing to 21% between 6 to 7 months of age.
There may be frequent episodes of regurgitation (5% of those affected have 6 or more episodes each day)
Reflux usually becomes less frequent as the infant gets older (it resolves in 90% of affected infants before they are 1 year of age).
Reflux does not usually require further investigation or treatment.
The incidence of GORD in Western Europe and North America is increasing and estimated to be 10% to 20%. Some patient groups have a much higher prevalence (see Table 1 below).

To date, no single symptom or cluster of symptoms can reliably be used to diagnose oesophagitis or other complications of GORD in infants or to predict which patients are most likely to respond to therapy (see Table 2 below).

data.text: GORD can present in a wide variety of symptoms and not just vomiting.
In Infants, with vomiting or regurgitation they may have ‘red flag' symptoms which  may suggest a disorder other than GORD
Symptoms of gastrointestinal obstruction or disease:
Onset of vomiting after six months of life*
Recurrent pneumonia (raises possibility of tracheoesophageal fistula);
Symptoms or signs suggesting systemic or neurologic disease:
Symptoms with an (*) are consequences of GORD

GORD is mainly a clinical diagnosis based on history and examination. Sometimes further tests would be warranted as below. This should be done by a specialist Paediatrician who might also liaise with tertiary centres.
This is more reliable, although false negatives occur. Indications:
Where apnoea is suspected to relate to GOR;
Where there is doubt about the diagnosis, because there is no spilling or vomiting.
The main purpose of a barium swallow is to exclude structural abnormalities:
Malrotation of the upper GI tract.
Upper GI endoscopy, is done in a select few refractory cases to exclude Eosinophilic Oesophagitis.
Management for GOR should be conservative and medications tried only if conservative methods do not work.

Positioning: semi-upright and upright position. In infants they should be fed in a semi upright position and should be kept upright for 15-30 mins after their feed. Sleeping babies should not be left semi-upright but allowed to sleep in the supine position to reduce the risk of SIDS.
Lifestyle changes: Avoiding Tobacco smoke exposure.
A feed plan/Dietary manipulation: should be made to keep a record of the type of feed, how much feed is taken, how often the feeds are given and if there is any vomiting and in what quantities.
Reduce feed volume if taking in excess of 150ml/k/day
Offer a trial of 1-2week of giving small and frequent feeds.
If overreaching centiles, ml/kg reduction can be made under medical supervision.
Do not reduce feeds(ml/kg),if growth is faltering.
Also, advise regular weight checks with health visitor.
For breastfed infants with frequent regurgitation and marked distress:
Consider 2-week trial of alginate therapy (Gaviscon Infant) and if there is an improvement continue with the treatment. If no improvement stop the treatment and consider other medications.
Advise parents to stop treatment at every 2-week interval in order to see any improvement in the symptoms.
For formula-fed infants with frequent regurgitation and marked distress:

10.2.1 Offer a 1–2 week trial of feed thickeners, such as a pre-thickened formula (for example Enfamil AR® and SMA Staydown®) or a thickener that can be added to the usual infant formula (for example Instant Carobel®).
Enfamil AR® and SMA Staydown® are both indicated for a maximum of 6 months — a normal teat can be used.
Instant Carobel® — a teat with a larger hole or a variable flow (split) will be required.
10.2.2 If no improvement, stop the thickened formula and offer a 1–2 week trial of alginate therapy (Gaviscon® Infant) added to formula.
10.2.3 If symptoms improve after a 2-week trial of alginate therapy:
Advise the parents or carers to stop treatment at regular intervals (for example every 2 weeks) in order to see if symptoms have improved and if it is possible to stop treatment completely.
If no improvement, consider other medications.
If symptoms remain troublesome despite a 1–2 week trial of alginate therapy in both breastfed and formula-fed infants:
10.3.1 Consider prescribing a 4-week trial of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI, such as omeprazole suspension [unlicensed use]) or a histamine-2 receptor antagonist
(H RAs, such as oral ranitidine [off-label use]) for infants who have overt
regurgitation with 1 or more of the following:
Unexplained feeding difficulties (for example, refusing feeds, gagging or choking);
10.3.2 Do not offer acid-suppressing drugs, such as proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) or
H receptor antagonists (H RAs), to treat overt regurgitation in infants occurring as
10.3.3 Assess the response to the 4-week trial of the PPI or HRA[], and consider referral to a specialist for possible endoscopy if the symptoms:
Prokinetics: Medicines such as Cisapride, Domperidone. There is insufficient evidence to support routine use. Needs specialist advice/tertiary input before commencing these medicines.
Do not offer metoclopramide, domperidone or erythromycin[] to treat GOR or GORD unless all of the following conditions are met:
The potential benefits outweigh the risk of adverse events,
There is specialist paediatric healthcare professional agreement for its use.

If there is a history of Atopy or Cow's Milk Protein Allergy (CMPA) or symptoms suggestive of CMPA then give a 4-week trial of CMP exclusion, hydrolysed formula, (refer to flowchart below) and reassess after 4-week. If there is any improvement continue and consider discussing of re introducing the cow's milk. When commencing these formulas, a dietitian referral is necessary according to the appropriate pathway.

Surgical therapies (fundoplication, surgical jejunostomy) are reserved for children with intractable symptoms or who are at risk for life-threatening complications of GORD (1). Careful patient selection is one of the keys to successful outcome. Clinical  conditions,  such  as  cyclic  vomiting,  rumination,  gastroparesis,  and eosinophilic esophagitis, should be carefully ruled out before surgery, because they are likely to still cause symptoms after surgery.

data.text: As a minimum the specific requirements will be monitored:
Breast fed babies to receive a 2 week trial of Gaviscon® with follow up;
Formula fed babies will have a 1-2 week trial of feed thickeners, then Gaviscon® and then medication;
Timing and indications of prescription of Hydrolysed formula.
